elements.title: Renunciation Gradient Value-Delivery Sequencing Test
elements.problem: If the platform demands two consecutive disclosures without an intervening value delivery, hosts experience compounded instinctual sacrifice and abandon at a higher rate than single-demand transitions. The renunciation gradient becomes invisible to the team, and new features silently raise the gradient at specific phases without compensating value.
elements.solution: Map every phase transition and measure whether a concrete value signal (earnings estimate, demand data, agent introduction, comparable pricing) precedes each disclosure request. Track phase-to-phase continuation rates and correlate drops with value-gap density.

evidence.quote: Any flow that requires users to give information before seeing results will lose most of them. Show something useful first. Offer to refine after.
evidence.insight: Rod's principle establishes the testable axiom: every ask without a preceding value demonstration is a measurable violation of the gradient design.

evidence.quote: If the deprivation is not made good economically, one may be certain of producing serious disorders.
evidence.insight: Freud predicts that uncompensated deprivation produces measurable behavioral disorders -- in platform terms, abandonment clusters at the point of uncompensated demand.

elements.test_description: Instrument every phase transition with two event markers: (1) value_signal_shown (timestamp when a concrete value element renders -- earnings estimate, demand signal, agent photo, comparable listing) and (2) disclosure_requested (timestamp when a form field, upload prompt, or identity request renders). Measure the time gap and sequence. For each transition where disclosure_requested fires before value_signal_shown, flag as a gradient violation. Correlate gradient violations with phase-to-phase dropout rates.
elements.success_criteria: No single phase transition has disclosure_requested firing before value_signal_shown. Phase-to-phase continuation rate is above 60% for every transition within the same session, with special focus on evaluation-to-onboarding and onboarding-to-listing-creation transitions.
elements.failure_meaning: A transition where disclosure precedes value indicates the renunciation gradient is steeper than the value delivery at that point. Hosts at that transition are experiencing what Freud calls uncompensated cultural privation -- they are being asked to surrender without having received anything first. This is a structural design defect, not a content problem.
elements.implementation_hint: Add analytics events for value_signal_rendered and disclosure_field_rendered at every phase boundary. Create a dashboard that shows the sequence per transition and flags inversions. Run weekly to catch regressions from new feature additions.

elements.title: Pause vs. Delete Reversibility Adoption Test
elements.problem: If the pause mechanism is unavailable, hard to find, or functionally identical to delete (e.g., paused listings degrade over time), hosts who experience temporary instinctual need for autonomy are forced into permanent exit. The platform loses hosts who would have returned.
elements.solution: Track the ratio of pause actions to delete actions, measure pause-to-reactivation rates over 6 months, and verify that paused listings retain 100% of their data integrity upon reactivation.

evidence.source: user-stories-initial-analysis.md, 'Pause matters more than delete' section
evidence.quote: Pause preserves the work, keeps the door open, and costs nothing. Delete is a one-way door that creates regret.
evidence.insight: Rod identifies the behavioral signal: hosts who stop are not always done. The test must verify that the system distinguishes between temporary withdrawal and permanent exit.

evidence.quote: The desire for freedom that makes itself felt in a human community may be a revolt against some existing injustice and so may prove favourable to a further development of civilization and remain compatible with it.
evidence.insight: Freud's two types of freedom-seeking (civilized revolt vs. primitive autonomy) predict that a significant proportion of exits are temporary. The pause-to-reactivation rate measures this directly.

elements.test_description: After pause feature deployment, track: (1) Pause-to-delete ratio (how many hosts choose pause vs. delete when both are offered). (2) Pause-to-reactivation rate at 30, 60, 90, and 180 days. (3) Data integrity audit: for every reactivated listing, verify that photos, descriptions, pricing, and rules are identical to the pre-pause state. (4) Permanent deletion rate reduction compared to pre-pause baseline.
elements.success_criteria: Pause-to-reactivation rate above 40% within 6 months. Permanent listing deletions reduced by 50% compared to pre-pause baseline. 100% data integrity on reactivated listings (zero fields lost or degraded).
elements.failure_meaning: If reactivation rate is below 40%, either the pause mechanism is not visible enough (hosts do not know it exists), or the reactivation path has friction that converts temporary pauses into permanent exits. If data integrity fails, the platform is betraying the host's civilizational investment -- the one thing pause was designed to protect.
elements.implementation_hint: Ensure pause is the primary action in any deactivation flow, with delete buried behind a secondary menu. Reactivation must be a single-tap action from the dashboard. Run a data integrity check on every reactivation event to catch any storage or migration bugs that could degrade paused listings.

elements.title: Proposal Structure as Civilizational Compliance Signal Test
elements.problem: If proposals arrive with missing fields or vague information, hosts default to instinctual distrust and either freeze (no response) or decline. The proposal structure fails to signal that the guest has submitted to marketplace rules, which is the primary mechanism for reducing stranger-threat anxiety.
elements.solution: Measure proposal completeness rate, correlate completeness with host response rate and acceptance rate, and verify that all required fields are enforced before submission.

evidence.quote: A well-structured proposal -- clear dates, schedule, pricing, intent -- activates the host to respond. A vague or incomplete one creates friction.
evidence.insight: Rod establishes the testable hypothesis: proposal completeness directly predicts host activation. The test must verify this correlation with actual behavioral data.

evidence.quote: Men are not gentle, friendly creatures wishing for love... but that a powerful measure of desire for aggression has to be reckoned as part of their instinctual endowment.
evidence.insight: Freud predicts that incomplete proposals amplify the host's default distrust because they lack the civilizational compliance signals that would counteract instinctual aggression toward the stranger.

elements.test_description: Track proposal completeness score (percentage of required fields filled: dates, schedule, pricing, stated reason for stay, verification status). Correlate completeness with: (1) host response rate within 48 hours, (2) acceptance rate, (3) counter-proposal rate, (4) no-response rate. Compare proposals from verified guests with prior lease history against first-time unverified guests.
elements.success_criteria: Proposal response rate (accept + counter + decline, excluding no-response) above 80% within 48 hours. Acceptance rate of first proposals from verified guests with prior lease history above 50%. No proposals submitted with fewer than 4 of 5 required fields completed.
elements.failure_meaning: Low response rates on complete proposals indicate trust signals are insufficient even when present -- the information architecture may need to surface them more prominently. High no-response rates on incomplete proposals confirm the civilizational compliance hypothesis but indicate the platform is still allowing uncivilized proposals through.
elements.implementation_hint: Enforce minimum required fields on the proposal form. Pre-populate dates and pricing from the listing to reduce guest effort while ensuring completeness. Surface guest verification status and lease history as the first data block in the proposal view.

elements.title: Active-Lease Ritual Cadence Completion Rate Test
elements.problem: If stay cycle rituals (arrival confirmation, cleaning photos, micro-reviews) are optional, inconsistently delivered, or skipped without consequence, the host loses the predictable order that Freud identifies as the civilizational mechanism for anxiety reduction. Information voids between stays fill with anxiety rather than confirmation.
elements.solution: Track ritual completion rate per stay cycle across all active leases. Measure the three-beat cadence (arrival signal, cleaning photos, micro-review) and correlate completion rates with host re-listing behavior at retention.

evidence.quote: Order is a kind of repetition-compulsion by which it is ordained once for all when, where and how a thing shall be done so that on every similar occasion doubt and hesitation shall be avoided.
evidence.insight: Freud predicts that ritual reliability -- not just ritual existence -- is what reduces anxiety. The test must measure completion rate, not just availability.

evidence.source: user-stories-initial-analysis.md, 'Urgency should surface first on the dashboard' section
evidence.quote: Unread proposals, pending actions, incomplete listings -- that's what a host needs to see the moment they log in.
evidence.insight: Rod's urgency principle extends to ritual confirmations: the host must see the latest ritual status immediately, which requires the rituals to actually be completed and surfaced.

elements.test_description: For every active lease, track per-stay-cycle: (1) arrival confirmation submitted (yes/no, timestamp), (2) cleaning photos submitted (yes/no, count, timestamp relative to departure), (3) micro-review submitted by host (yes/no, timestamp). Calculate ritual completion rate as percentage of stays where all three beats are completed. Correlate full-cycle completion rate with host re-listing rate at lease end.
elements.success_criteria: Ritual completion rate (all three beats completed by both parties) above 70% of all stay cycles. Positive correlation between ritual completion rate and host re-listing rate at retention (r > 0.3).
elements.failure_meaning: Low ritual completion means the civilizational order mechanism is not functioning -- hosts are in an information void that produces anxiety rather than calm. If no correlation exists between ritual completion and re-listing, the rituals may be perceived as chores rather than reassurance, requiring redesign of the ritual interaction pattern.
elements.implementation_hint: Make arrival confirmation and cleaning photos required for the guest (with platform follow-up if missed). Make micro-reviews optional but consistently prompted. Surface completion status on the host dashboard's stay card in real time.

elements.title: Host Identity and Cumulative Narrative Retention Impact Test
elements.problem: Without a visible cumulative hosting narrative (total earnings, successful stays, review trajectory), hosts perform retrospective cost-benefit analysis anchored on negative minor grievances rather than cumulative positive value. The narcissism of minor differences drives permanent exit.
elements.solution: A/B test the Hosting Summary surface at lease-end, measuring re-listing rates with and without cumulative narrative visibility.

evidence.quote: Civilized man has exchanged some part of his chances of happiness for a measure of security.
evidence.insight: If the 'measure of security' is not made visible at the retention moment, the host only remembers the 'chances of happiness' they exchanged. The A/B test isolates the impact of making security tangible.

evidence.quote: A skeptical guest who sees verified reviews, ID checks, and real host history doesn't need the platform to convince them -- another user already did.
evidence.insight: Inverted for retention: the host's own hosting history should do the convincing. The test measures whether showing the history actually changes behavior.

elements.test_description: At lease end, randomly assign hosts to: (A) control -- standard lease-end notification with re-listing CTA, no cumulative summary; (B) treatment -- Hosting Summary surface showing total earnings, successful stays, average rating, hosting tenure, followed by the same re-listing CTA. Measure re-listing rate within 60 days for both groups. Secondary: measure time-to-reactivation and engagement with the summary (scroll depth, dwell time).
elements.success_criteria: Treatment group re-listing rate exceeds control by at least 15 percentage points. Target: above 50% re-listing rate within 60 days for the treatment group.
elements.failure_meaning: If the cumulative narrative does not improve re-listing rates, either the narrative is not presented compellingly enough (visual design issue), or the host's retention decision is driven by factors the narrative does not address (e.g., specific unresolved grievances, life changes). Investigate qualitative reasons for non-relisting in the treatment group.
elements.implementation_hint: Display the Hosting Summary prominently on the dashboard 24 hours after the final stay completes. Use hero-scale typography for total earnings. Ensure the 'Continue Hosting' CTA appears directly below the summary with one-tap reactivation.

elements.title: Platform Mediation Justice Perception Test
elements.problem: If the host perceives platform rules as one-sided bureaucratic constraints rather than bidirectional protections, they develop civilizational antagonism -- the feeling that the platform controls them rather than protects them. This antagonism accumulates across encounters and drives exit at retention.
elements.solution: Measure host satisfaction with platform fairness after encountering constraint surfaces. Track support ticket volume for process confusion. Conduct qualitative interviews about the host's perception of platform rules.

evidence.quote: The first requisite of culture, therefore, is justice -- that is, the assurance that a law once made will not be broken in favour of any individual.
evidence.insight: Freud predicts that perceived injustice (one-sided rules) produces antagonism toward the system. The test measures whether bidirectional framing converts this perceived injustice into perceived protection.

evidence.source: user-stories-initial-analysis.md, 'Messaging before proposals is a natural step' section
evidence.quote: The park analogy holds -- you check availability before committing.
evidence.insight: The park analogy suggests that intermediate, low-stakes steps (like viewing bidirectional protections) reduce the emotional intensity of civilizational demands. The test must measure whether the framing actually achieves this.

elements.test_description: Track support ticket volume categorized as 'process confusion' (tickets containing phrases like 'why do I need to,' 'why can't I,' 'I don't understand why'). Measure before and after implementing bidirectional protection framing on all constraint surfaces. Additionally, embed a single-question satisfaction pulse after the host's first 3 constraint encounters: 'Do you feel the platform's rules protect you fairly?' (yes/no).
elements.success_criteria: Support ticket volume for process confusion reduced by 30% within 3 months of implementing visible bidirectional justice framing. Host satisfaction with platform fairness above 70% positive responses.
elements.failure_meaning: If support tickets do not decrease, the bidirectional framing is not reaching the host at the moment of constraint encounter -- the framing may be too small, too subtle, or placed after the host has already formed a negative impression. If satisfaction is low despite framing, the rules themselves may be perceived as genuinely unfair, requiring policy review.
elements.implementation_hint: Apply the bidirectional protection frame to every confirmation dialog, approval flow, and date change restriction. Lead with 'Both parties are protected' before describing any constraint. Ensure the protection headline uses the reassurance typographic register (bold, brand purple).

elements.title: Progressive Disclosure Sequencing Compliance Test
elements.problem: If the information architecture requests host information before delivering platform value at any phase transition, the host experiences uncompensated cultural privation. The progressive disclosure sequence may be violated by new features, A/B tests, or layout changes that inadvertently place a request before a value signal.
elements.solution: Conduct a quarterly audit of every phase transition screen, mapping the order of information elements: platform value disclosures vs. host information requests. Automate with page-level event tracking.

evidence.quote: Any flow that requires users to give information before seeing results will lose most of them.
evidence.insight: Rod's principle is the audit criterion: for every screen in the phase sequence, the first rendered content element must be a value signal, not a request.

evidence.quote: If the deprivation is not made good economically, one may be certain of producing serious disorders.
evidence.insight: Freud's warning translates into a testable rule: every disclosure request without a preceding value delivery is a deprivation that the audit must flag.

elements.test_description: For each phase transition (discovery landing, evaluation page, onboarding flow, listing wizard entry), document the first 5 content elements in visual scan order. Classify each as value_signal (earnings estimate, demand data, agent photo, guarantee badge) or disclosure_request (form field, upload prompt, identity verification, terms checkbox). A phase passes if the first content element is a value_signal. A phase fails if any disclosure_request appears before a value_signal.
elements.success_criteria: 100% of phase transitions pass: first rendered content element is a value_signal in every case. The 2:1 ratio (two platform value disclosures for every one host disclosure) is maintained across the full sequence.
elements.failure_meaning: A failed audit indicates the progressive disclosure principle has been violated at a specific transition. The failure is structural (information architecture sequencing) and must be resolved by reordering elements, not by adding more value signals downstream.
elements.implementation_hint: Create a visual audit checklist showing each phase transition screen with elements numbered in scan order. Mark each as V (value) or D (disclosure). Review quarterly and after any major feature deployment.

elements.title: Bidirectional Protection Framing Comprehension Test
elements.problem: If the bidirectional framing is present but not understood -- if hosts read 'Date changes require mutual agreement' but do not register that the guest is equally constrained -- the framing fails to convert perceived oppression into perceived protection. The information architecture must achieve comprehension, not just exposure.
elements.solution: Conduct moderated usability tests where hosts encounter constraint surfaces and are asked to explain in their own words what the rule means for them and for the guest.

evidence.quote: The first requisite of culture, therefore, is justice -- that is, the assurance that a law once made will not be broken in favour of any individual.
evidence.insight: Freud's justice principle requires not just that the rule is fair but that it is perceived as fair. The test measures perception, not just presentation.

evidence.quote: The park analogy holds -- you check availability before committing.
evidence.insight: The park bench metaphor suggests the constraint surface should feel like a natural pause for understanding, not a legal notice. The usability test measures whether hosts experience it that way.

elements.test_description: Recruit 8-10 hosts (mix of new and experienced). Present each with 3 constraint surfaces (date change approval, proposal decline confirmation, schedule modification). After each, ask: (1) 'In your own words, what does this rule mean?' (2) 'Does this rule apply to you, the guest, or both?' (3) 'Do you feel this rule protects you, constrains you, or both?' Score responses on bidirectional comprehension (did they mention the guest's constraint without prompting?) and emotional register (protection vs. constraint vs. neutral).
elements.success_criteria: At least 7 of 10 hosts spontaneously identify the bidirectional nature of the constraint (mentioning the guest's reciprocal limitation without being prompted). At least 8 of 10 rate the rule as protective or both protective and constraining, rather than purely constraining.
elements.failure_meaning: If hosts do not register the bidirectional nature, the framing is too subtle, the bidirectional statement is buried below the fold, or the constraint headline overshadows the protection headline. Redesign the scan order to ensure the protection assertion is the first thing read.
elements.implementation_hint: In the usability test, use think-aloud protocol. Watch for the moment the host's eyes scan past or skip the bidirectional statement. If they consistently miss it, increase its visual weight (larger type, stronger color contrast, or position it as the first line rather than the second).

elements.title: Stranger Threat Reduction Speed Test
elements.problem: If trust signals (verification status, completed leases, review rating, stated purpose) are not immediately visible when the host opens a proposal, the host's instinctual distrust crystallizes into rejection or inaction before rational evaluation can begin. The information architecture must resolve the stranger-threat question within 3 seconds.
elements.solution: Measure time-to-first-action on proposals and correlate with the visibility of trust signals. Conduct eye-tracking studies to verify the scan order places trust before terms.

evidence.quote: Men are not gentle, friendly creatures wishing for love... but that a powerful measure of desire for aggression has to be reckoned as part of their instinctual endowment.
evidence.insight: Freud establishes that the host's default response to a stranger is distrust. The test measures whether the information architecture resolves this distrust fast enough to enable rational evaluation.

evidence.quote: When someone who's already used Split Lease applies to a host who's never had a guest, that guest's reputation does the selling.
evidence.insight: Rod confirms that trust evidence must be self-evident and immediate. The test verifies that the proposal view delivers this evidence in the first scan zone.

elements.test_description: Recruit 6-8 hosts. Show each a proposal view and measure: (1) Time from proposal open to first verbal assessment of the guest (e.g., 'this person seems reliable'). Target: under 3 seconds. (2) Eye-tracking: does the host's gaze land on the trust block (verification, leases, rating) before the terms block (dates, pricing)? (3) Can the host answer 'Is this person verified?' and 'Have they stayed with other hosts?' without scrolling or navigating away from the proposal view?
elements.success_criteria: Host resolves the 'is this person safe?' question within 3 seconds of opening the proposal. Eye-tracking confirms trust block is scanned before terms block in at least 7 of 8 participants. 100% of hosts can answer verification and history questions without scrolling.
elements.failure_meaning: If trust resolution takes longer than 3 seconds, the trust signals are either too small, positioned below the fold, or visually indistinct from surrounding content. If the host scans terms before trust, the information hierarchy is inverted and needs restructuring.
elements.implementation_hint: Place the trust data block (verification icon, lease count, rating score, member since, stated purpose) as the first content region of the proposal view, above the terms section. Use the evidence typographic register (semibold, distinct from body text) and icon-first layout for instant recognition.

elements.title: Urgency-First Dashboard Scan Efficiency Test
elements.problem: If the dashboard does not consistently surface action-required items in a fixed position at the top, the host must scan the entire page to determine what needs attention. This scanning effort violates Freud's order principle and produces the doubt and hesitation that a structured dashboard should eliminate.
elements.solution: Measure task-finding speed on the dashboard: how quickly can a host identify the most urgent pending action? Compare fixed three-tier layout vs. alternative layouts.

evidence.quote: Urgency should surface first on the dashboard. Unread proposals, pending actions, incomplete listings -- that's what a host needs to see the moment they log in.
evidence.insight: Rod defines the test criterion: the most urgent item must be the first thing the host sees. The test measures whether the dashboard achieves this.

evidence.quote: Order is a kind of repetition-compulsion by which it is ordained once for all when, where and how a thing shall be done so that on every similar occasion doubt and hesitation shall be avoided.
evidence.insight: Freud predicts that a consistent, fixed layout saves mental energy. The test measures whether hosts find urgent items faster on a fixed layout than on a dynamic one.

elements.test_description: Recruit 8 hosts. Show each the dashboard with 2 action-required items, 3 status updates, and 2 informational items. Task: 'What needs your attention right now?' Measure: (1) time to identify the first action-required item, (2) accuracy (did they identify the correct items?), (3) eye-tracking: did their gaze start in the top zone? Repeat across 3 visits with different content to verify the host learns the layout and speeds improve on subsequent visits.
elements.success_criteria: Time to identify first action-required item under 5 seconds on first visit, under 3 seconds on third visit. Accuracy above 90% (host correctly identifies all action-required items). Eye-tracking confirms top-zone entry point in 7 of 8 participants.
elements.failure_meaning: If identification takes longer than 5 seconds or accuracy is below 90%, the three-tier hierarchy is not visually distinct enough -- the action-required zone may blend with the status zone. If gaze does not start in the top zone, the visual hierarchy needs stronger differentiation (background tint, badge prominence, zone spacing).
elements.implementation_hint: Use distinct background tints for each zone (white for action, off-white for status, light gray for informational). Amber badges on action items create warm-spectrum pop against the cool/neutral ambient palette. Test with the exact production color tokens.

elements.title: Ritual Confirmation Cadence Information Delivery Test
elements.problem: If the three-signal confirmation cadence (arrival, cleaning photos, health summary) is not delivered at predictable intervals, or if missed signals are not communicated neutrally, the host's anxiety fills the information void. The cadence itself becomes unreliable, undermining the order mechanism.
elements.solution: Track cadence delivery timing for every stay cycle and measure deviation from the expected rhythm. Survey hosts on their perception of the cadence's reliability.

evidence.quote: The benefits of order are incontestable: it enables us to use space and time to the best advantage, while saving expenditure of mental energy.
evidence.insight: Freud predicts that cadence reliability -- not just cadence existence -- determines its anxiety-reduction effect. The test measures reliability.

evidence.quote: Unread proposals, pending actions, incomplete listings -- that's what a host needs to see the moment they log in.
evidence.insight: The dashboard must surface ritual status in the same structured way as proposals. The test verifies that ritual confirmations appear proactively without host effort.

elements.test_description: For each stay cycle, measure: (1) Arrival confirmation delivery time (gap between guest confirmation event and host dashboard update). Target: under 60 seconds. (2) Cleaning photo delivery time (gap between guest photo upload completion and host dashboard thumbnail appearance). Target: under 5 minutes. (3) Health summary generation time (gap between stay completion and auto-generated summary appearance). Target: under 24 hours. Track percentage of cycles where all three signals are delivered on time vs. delayed or missed.
elements.success_criteria: 95% of stay cycles deliver all three confirmation signals within target windows. For the remaining 5% (missed or delayed), the platform sends a neutral status message to the host within 12 hours of the expected delivery time.
elements.failure_meaning: If delivery reliability falls below 95%, the cadence is not predictable enough to serve as an anxiety-reduction mechanism. The host cannot rely on it, which means they must actively monitor -- exactly the behavior the ritual was designed to eliminate.
elements.implementation_hint: Implement real-time event listeners for guest confirmation actions that immediately update the host's dashboard via WebSocket or server-sent events. Set automated fallback: if a ritual signal is not received within the target window, trigger the platform follow-up to the guest and the neutral status message to the host.

elements.title: Cumulative Investment Narrative Visibility and Impact Test
elements.problem: If the Hosting Summary is not surfaced prominently at lease-end and return-from-pause moments, hosts make the retention decision without the cumulative evidence needed to counteract the narcissism of minor differences. The retrospective assessment defaults to negativity.
elements.solution: Verify Hosting Summary visibility at the correct moments and measure its impact on host emotional state and re-listing behavior.

evidence.quote: Civilized man has exchanged some part of his chances of happiness for a measure of security.
evidence.insight: The test measures whether making the 'measure of security' visible at the retention moment actually changes the host's behavior. If the exchange is not perceived as net-positive, visibility alone is insufficient.

evidence.quote: Pause preserves the work, keeps the door open, and costs nothing.
evidence.insight: For returning-from-pause hosts, the Hosting Summary must show that their preserved investment is intact and valuable. The test verifies this specific moment.

elements.test_description: Recruit 6 hosts at or near lease end. Show each the Hosting Summary surface. Measure: (1) Can the host state their total earnings without prompting? (2) Does the host express positive surprise or recognition at the cumulative figure? (3) After viewing the summary, does the host express willingness to continue hosting? Compare with 6 hosts shown a standard lease-end notification without the summary.
elements.success_criteria: At least 5 of 6 hosts who view the Hosting Summary can accurately recall their total earnings and rate the summary as 'motivating' or 'encouraging.' Willingness to continue hosting is higher in the summary group than the control group.
elements.failure_meaning: If the summary does not produce recognition or motivation, the numbers may be presented without sufficient emotional weight (too small, wrong typographic register, or buried among other dashboard content). If hosts recall the number but are not motivated, their grievances outweigh the financial evidence -- investigate specific unresolved issues.
elements.implementation_hint: Present total earnings at hero scale (36px, brand purple). Place the summary in the action-required zone at lease end, not in the informational tier. Ensure it appears before any re-listing prompt.

elements.title: Warm Containment Visual Trust Priming Test
elements.problem: If containers feel cold, clinical, or institutional (flat, sharp-cornered, thin gray borders), the host's System 1 rejects the visual environment before any content is evaluated. The visual surface itself becomes a civilizational demand rather than a protective enclosure.
elements.solution: Conduct A/B preference testing comparing warm containers (rounded, purple-tinted backgrounds, subtle shadows) against clinical containers (sharp, plain white, standard gray borders) on key conversion surfaces.

evidence.quote: We soon become aware that the useless thing which we require of civilization is beauty.
evidence.insight: Freud identifies beauty as a non-utilitarian but essential civilizational requirement. The test measures whether warm visual containers satisfy this requirement and produce measurably different engagement.

evidence.quote: Any flow that requires users to give information before seeing results will lose most of them. Show something useful first.
evidence.insight: The visual container must communicate warmth and safety pre-cognitively, before any content is read. The test isolates the container's visual treatment from the content inside it.

elements.test_description: On a high-traffic conversion surface (listing wizard step 1 or proposal review page), randomly assign hosts to: (A) warm containers (rounded-xl, --bg-off-white, --shadow-purple-sm, 24px padding) vs. (B) clinical containers (4px radius, white background, standard gray shadow, 16px padding). Measure: time-on-page, completion rate for the step, and qualitative preference (post-task single question: 'How did this page feel?').
elements.success_criteria: Warm container variant shows at least 10% higher step completion rate and qualitative preference score skewing toward 'welcoming' or 'trustworthy' rather than 'neutral' or 'professional.'
elements.failure_meaning: If no measurable difference exists, the warm containment pattern may be too subtle to register or the host audience may not be sensitive to container styling at the current level of differentiation. Increase the warmth differential (more pronounced rounding, deeper purple tint, larger padding gap).
elements.implementation_hint: Use exact production tokens: --rounded-xl (12px), --bg-off-white (rgb(252, 250, 255)), --shadow-purple-sm. Ensure the warm variant is visually distinct enough to produce a detectable preference signal -- subtle differences may not be measurable in an A/B test.

elements.title: Purple Authority Hierarchy Discipline Audit
elements.problem: If deep primary purple (#31135D) is used on non-authority elements (decorative cards, informational sections), the host cannot distinguish platform guarantees from general content. The trust signal dilutes. Purple everywhere becomes wallpaper; purple at authority moments becomes meaningless.
elements.solution: Audit every surface where primary purple appears and verify it is used exclusively on authority-level elements: header bar, payment guarantee badges, confirmation states, and platform identity markers.

evidence.quote: The first requisite of culture, therefore, is justice -- that is, the assurance that a law once made will not be broken in favour of any individual.
evidence.insight: Primary purple is the platform's visual law -- the mark of authoritative assertions. Using it on non-authoritative content dilutes the signal that tells hosts when the platform is standing behind something.

evidence.quote: --primary-purple (#31135D): Brand color, headings, important UI elements, header backgrounds.
evidence.insight: The production style guide establishes the constraint: primary purple is for important UI elements. The audit verifies compliance.

elements.test_description: Conduct a full-page visual audit of every production screen. For each instance of --primary-purple (#31135D), classify its usage as: (1) Authority (header, guarantee badge, confirmation state, identity marker) or (2) Non-authority (decorative card, informational section, body text, secondary UI element). Count and list all non-authority usages. Repeat for --gradient-purple-primary.
elements.success_criteria: 100% of primary purple and gradient-purple-primary usages are on authority-level elements. Zero non-authority usages. The four-tier hierarchy (authority > action > hover > ambient) is maintained throughout.
elements.failure_meaning: Any non-authority usage of primary purple indicates hierarchy discipline failure. The more non-authority usages, the weaker the trust signal. Each violation must be resolved by either promoting the element to authority level (if it genuinely represents a platform guarantee) or demoting the color to secondary or accent purple.
elements.implementation_hint: Create a CSS linting rule or design token audit script that flags any usage of --primary-purple or --gradient-purple-primary outside of designated authority component classes (header, guarantee-badge, confirmation-state).

elements.title: Typographic Register Differentiation Comprehension Test
elements.problem: If all text looks the same -- if reassurance headlines, action instructions, and evidence data use the same typographic treatment -- the host cannot distinguish between what the platform is promising (reassurance), what the platform is asking (action), and what the platform can prove (evidence). The civilizational signals blur together.
elements.solution: Test whether hosts can correctly identify the type of information (promise, instruction, data) based solely on typographic treatment, without reading the content.

evidence.quote: Beauty, cleanliness and order clearly occupy a peculiar position among the requirements of civilization.
evidence.insight: Typography is the primary vehicle for order in a digital interface. The test measures whether the three registers produce distinguishable visual patterns that the host can reliably decode.

evidence.quote: Serif for personality. Sans for clarity. Mono for data/trust.
evidence.insight: The taste model prescribes three registers. The test verifies that the implementation achieves the intended perceptual differentiation.

elements.test_description: Show 8 hosts a screen with 6 text elements (2 reassurance headlines, 2 action instructions, 2 evidence data points) using the three typographic registers. Ask each host to group the elements into 3 categories based on visual appearance alone (before reading content). Measure: (1) grouping accuracy (do they correctly separate the three registers?), (2) label assignment (can they characterize each group as 'headline/promise,' 'instruction,' or 'data/proof'?).
elements.success_criteria: At least 6 of 8 hosts correctly group the 6 elements into 3 distinct visual categories. At least 5 of 8 assign appropriate functional labels to each group.
elements.failure_meaning: If hosts cannot distinguish the registers, the typographic differentiation is insufficient. The registers may be too similar in weight, size, or color. Increase the differentiation: larger size gap between registers, stronger weight contrast, or introduce the monospace face for evidence to create a more distinctive third register.
elements.implementation_hint: For maximum differentiation, ensure at least a 2-step weight gap between registers (e.g., reassurance at 700, action at 400, evidence at 600). If all three use the same typeface (Inter), the differentiation relies entirely on weight, size, and color -- consider adopting the taste model's monospace face for evidence.

elements.title: Amber Urgency vs. Red Alarm Emotional Response Test
elements.problem: If red is used for routine urgency indicators (unread proposals, pending actions, deadline counters), the host experiences alarm and anxiety rather than motivated attention. Red triggers the aggressive instinctual response that Freud describes, turning routine platform actions into perceived crises.
elements.solution: A/B test amber urgency badges vs. red urgency badges on dashboard notification elements, measuring emotional response and action completion rates.

evidence.quote: Culture has to call up every possible reinforcement in order to erect barriers against the aggressive instincts of men.
evidence.insight: The urgency signal system is one of the platform's barriers against aggressive instincts. If the signal itself triggers aggression (red = alarm), it defeats its own purpose.

evidence.quote: Amber for warnings/urgency (warm, not alarming). Red only for errors (never for CTAs or emphasis).
evidence.insight: The taste model explicitly prescribes this distinction. The test verifies that the implementation achieves the intended emotional differentiation.

elements.test_description: On the host dashboard, randomly assign: (A) amber urgency badges (--signal-warn on notification counts, --signal-warn-bg on urgency cards) vs. (B) red urgency badges (standard red notification counts, red-tinted urgency cards). Measure: (1) action completion rate for urgent items within 24 hours, (2) post-session survey: 'How did the dashboard make you feel?' with options including 'motivated,' 'calm,' 'anxious,' 'stressed,' 'neutral.'
elements.success_criteria: Amber variant shows equal or higher action completion rate compared to red. Amber variant shows significantly lower selection of 'anxious' and 'stressed' in the post-session survey. Red variant should be reserved for error states only.
elements.failure_meaning: If red produces higher action completion, urgency overrides emotional comfort -- but at the cost of accumulated stress. If amber produces equal completion without the anxiety, it is strictly superior. If amber produces lower completion, the urgency signal may be too subtle and needs strengthening (darker amber, larger badges).
elements.implementation_hint: Use exact tokens: --signal-warn (#c17a28) for badge background, --signal-warn-bg (#fef3e2) for card tint. Ensure amber badges maintain WCAG AA contrast. Test on both light and dark dashboard areas.

elements.title: Ritual Visual Cadence Layout Consistency Test
elements.problem: If the Stays Manager layout changes between visits -- cards move, sections reorder, information hierarchy shifts -- the host must relearn the interface each time. This violates Freud's repetition-compulsion principle and produces the doubt and hesitation that fixed layout is meant to eliminate.
elements.solution: Track layout consistency across visits and measure host orientation speed (time to locate a specific piece of information) on return visits.

evidence.quote: Order is a kind of repetition-compulsion by which it is ordained once for all when, where and how a thing shall be done so that on every similar occasion doubt and hesitation shall be avoided.
evidence.insight: Freud's repetition-compulsion requires that the layout is identical every visit. The test measures whether this is achieved and whether it produces the predicted orientation speed improvement.

evidence.quote: Urgency should surface first on the dashboard.
evidence.insight: Rod's urgency-first principle requires a fixed position for urgent items. The test verifies that the position is fixed across visits.

elements.test_description: Automated visual regression testing: capture the Stays Manager layout on every deployment and compare against the baseline layout. Flag any changes to: zone positions, card dimensions, spacing between zones, progress bar location, or action button placement. Additionally, measure host task speed across visits: 'Find the cleaning photos from the most recent stay.' Compare first-visit speed vs. third-visit speed.
elements.success_criteria: Zero layout changes to zone positions, card dimensions, or structural elements between deployments (content changes are expected; structural changes are flagged). Task speed improves by at least 30% between first and third visit, confirming the host is learning the layout.
elements.failure_meaning: Any unintended layout change indicates a deployment that violated the fixed-grid principle. If task speed does not improve across visits, the layout may be too complex for pattern recognition -- simplify the visual structure or increase the differentiation between zones.
elements.implementation_hint: Implement visual regression testing (e.g., Percy, Chromatic, or BackstopJS) with strict zone-position baselines. Create a design-system rule that Stays Manager layout changes require explicit approval as structural modifications.

elements.title: Retention Data Visualization Emotional Impact Test
elements.problem: If the Hosting Summary data visualization is visually flat (plain text list of numbers), it fails to produce the emotional impact needed to counteract the narcissism of minor differences. The cumulative evidence must be visually arresting -- large, confident, warm -- to shift the host's retrospective assessment.
elements.solution: Test host emotional response to the Hosting Summary at different visual scales and presentation styles.

evidence.quote: Civilized man has exchanged some part of his chances of happiness for a measure of security.
evidence.insight: The cumulative data must make the 'measure of security' feel like an achievement, not just a number. Visual scale and presentation style determine whether the host feels accomplishment or indifference.

evidence.quote: Pause preserves the work, keeps the door open, and costs nothing.
evidence.insight: For returning hosts, the Hosting Summary must visually demonstrate that their investment was preserved. The visual weight of the presentation signals the platform's respect for this investment.

elements.test_description: Show 6 hosts two versions of their Hosting Summary: (A) plain text format ($12,400 total earnings, 28 stays, 4.8 rating) and (B) hero-scale visualization (36px earnings in brand purple, supporting metrics with icons, hosting trajectory timeline). After each, ask: (1) 'How does this make you feel about your hosting?' (2) 'Would this influence whether you continue hosting?' (3) Rate the presentation on a 5-point 'sense of accomplishment' scale.
elements.success_criteria: Hero-scale visualization produces at least 1.5 points higher on the accomplishment scale than plain text. At least 5 of 6 hosts report the visualization would positively influence their re-listing decision.
elements.failure_meaning: If the hero visualization does not outperform plain text, the emotional impact of visual scale is weaker than expected for this audience -- the cumulative number itself may be the primary driver, not its presentation. Focus on ensuring the number is large and accurate rather than elaborating the visual treatment.
elements.implementation_hint: Use exact tokens: --text-4xl (36px) at --font-weight-bold (700) in --primary-purple for the earnings headline. Generous container padding (--spacing-4xl: 32px). Stagger metric entrance animations for emotional weight.

elements.title: Protection Surface Visual Pattern Recognition Test
elements.problem: If the bidirectional protection surface looks identical to generic confirmation modals (white box, gray text, two buttons), the host's System 1 reads it as bureaucracy before the protection framing can be processed. The visual pattern must be distinct enough to trigger a learned 'this protects me' response.
elements.solution: Test whether hosts develop a Pavlovian recognition of the warm purple protection surface after repeated exposure, associating it with safety rather than constraint.

evidence.quote: The first requisite of culture, therefore, is justice.
evidence.insight: The shield icon and protection headline visually encode justice. The test measures whether hosts develop the association between the visual pattern and the emotional experience of protection.

evidence.quote: --protocol-surface: #F7F2FA.
evidence.insight: The production token provides a visually distinct surface. The test verifies it is distinct enough to produce pattern recognition.

elements.test_description: Show 8 hosts 5 different dialog types in sequence: 2 protection surfaces (warm purple, shield icon) and 3 generic surfaces (white background, standard icons). After viewing all 5, ask: (1) 'Which dialogs felt like they were protecting you?' (2) 'Which felt like standard platform notifications?' Measure whether hosts consistently identify the warm purple surfaces as protective.
elements.success_criteria: At least 7 of 8 hosts correctly identify the protection surfaces as distinct from generic surfaces. At least 6 of 8 associate the warm purple surfaces with protection or safety language.
elements.failure_meaning: If hosts cannot distinguish the protection surface from generic dialogs, the visual differentiation is insufficient. Increase the distinction: deeper purple tint, larger shield icon, more prominent protection headline, or add a subtle border in brand purple.
elements.implementation_hint: Use --protocol-surface (#F7F2FA) as the background, --secondary-purple shield icon at 28px, and --primary-purple headline text. Test against actual generic modals in the production design system to ensure adequate differentiation.

elements.title: Optimistic Commit Perceived Response Time Test
elements.problem: If there is any perceptible delay between the host tapping Accept Proposal and seeing the success state, the host experiences doubt at the exact moment they have overcome their instinctual resistance to the stranger. A spinner reintroduces the hesitation that the host just resolved.
elements.solution: Measure perceived response time for civilizational acts (accept proposal, confirm stay, approve date change) and verify optimistic UI eliminates the gap between action and confirmation.

evidence.quote: If the deprivation is not made good economically, one may be certain of producing serious disorders.
evidence.insight: A spinner after a civilizational commitment is a micro-deprivation at the moment of maximum psychological cost. The test measures whether optimistic UI eliminates this deprivation.

evidence.quote: A well-structured proposal activates the host to respond.
evidence.insight: Activation is wasted if the response moment introduces friction. The test verifies that the activation-to-confirmation arc is seamless.

elements.test_description: Instrument the Accept Proposal, Confirm Stay, and Approve Date Change actions with client-side timing: (1) timestamp of button tap, (2) timestamp of success state render. Calculate perceived response time (gap between tap and visible success). Additionally, monitor background server call completion time and rollback rate.
elements.success_criteria: Perceived response time is 0ms (success state renders in the same frame as the button tap, or within 200ms for the transition animation). Background server call completes within 2000ms in 99% of cases. Rollback rate (server failure requiring UI revert) below 0.1%.
elements.failure_meaning: If perceived response time exceeds 200ms, the optimistic UI is not implemented correctly -- there is a synchronous server call blocking the UI update. If rollback rate exceeds 0.1%, the optimistic pattern may be creating trust issues when the host sees a success that is then reverted.
elements.implementation_hint: The success state must render client-side immediately on tap, with the server call dispatched asynchronously. Use requestAnimationFrame or equivalent to ensure the success state paints in the next frame. The server call uses fire-and-forget with a background promise that handles rollback only on failure.

elements.title: Graduated Friction for Irreversible Actions Test
elements.problem: If irreversible actions (delete listing, deactivate account) have the same interaction speed as reversible actions (pause listing), impulsive deletions destroy the host's civilizational investment. If reversible actions have too much friction (confirmation dialogs on pause), the friction discourages temporary retreats that would have resolved naturally.
elements.solution: Measure the correlation between friction level and action regret for pause vs. delete. Track whether the 5-second cool-down for delete reduces impulsive permanent exits.

evidence.quote: Pause matters more than delete. Hosts who stop a listing aren't always done with it.
evidence.insight: Rod's observation predicts that many deletes are impulsive rather than considered. The 5-second cool-down test measures whether a brief pause before irreversible action changes the outcome.

evidence.quote: The desire for freedom may have its origin in the primitive roots of the personality, still unfettered by civilizing influences.
evidence.insight: Freud predicts that some exits are driven by primitive impulse rather than settled decision. The graduated friction gives the civilized self time to catch up with the impulsive self.

elements.test_description: After implementing graduated friction: (1) Track abandonment rate at the 5-second cool-down (how many hosts who initiate delete abandon the action during the countdown). (2) Track re-creation rate (how many hosts who complete delete subsequently create a new listing, indicating regret). (3) Compare pause-to-reactivation rate vs. delete-and-recreate rate to quantify impulsive deletion impact.
elements.success_criteria: At least 20% of hosts who initiate delete abandon the action during the 5-second cool-down (indicating the cool-down caught impulsive decisions). Delete-and-recreate rate below 5% (indicating that hosts who complete delete genuinely intended to). Pause action has zero friction (no confirmation dialog, instant state change).
elements.failure_meaning: If fewer than 20% abandon during the cool-down, either the cool-down is too short or hosts who reach the delete flow have already made a deliberate decision. If delete-and-recreate is above 5%, the cool-down is not catching enough impulsive decisions -- consider extending the cool-down or adding the loss summary (what will be permanently deleted) more prominently.
elements.implementation_hint: The 5-second countdown should display on the button itself ('Delete in 5... 4... 3...'). During the countdown, show what will be permanently lost (photos, descriptions, reviews). Pause should be a single toggle with no confirmation -- instant, frictionless, and immediately reversible.

elements.title: Protective Error State Emotional Register Test
elements.problem: If error states use red text, exclamation marks, and blame-adjacent language ('Invalid input,' 'Upload failed'), the host experiences civilizational disappointment -- the platform repays their instinctual sacrifice with a punitive message. The aggressive instinct is activated toward the platform.
elements.solution: Test host emotional response to protective error messages vs. standard error messages across common error scenarios.

evidence.quote: Mankind is proud of its exploits... But men are beginning to perceive that all this newly won power has not increased the amount of pleasure they can obtain in life.
evidence.insight: Every platform error confirms civilizational disappointment. The test measures whether protective error states prevent this disappointment from converting into platform antagonism.

evidence.quote: Show something useful first. Offer to refine after.
evidence.insight: Applied to error recovery: confirm that prior work is safe (useful information) before asking the host to retry (refinement). The test measures whether this sequence reduces frustration.

elements.test_description: Show 8 hosts two versions of 3 common error scenarios (photo upload failure, form validation error, server timeout): (A) standard error messages (red text, 'Upload failed -- file too large,' 'Invalid input') vs. (B) protective error messages (amber background, 'This did not go through. Your listing progress is saved. Try uploading the photo again.'). After each, ask: (1) 'How did this make you feel?' (2) 'Do you know what to do next?' (3) 'Is your prior work safe?' Rate on a 5-point frustration scale.
elements.success_criteria: Protective error messages score at least 1.5 points lower on the frustration scale than standard error messages. 100% of hosts who see protective messages can identify the recovery action. 100% correctly understand their prior work is preserved.
elements.failure_meaning: If protective messages do not reduce frustration, the language may still feel blame-adjacent or the amber styling may not be differentiated enough from red. If hosts cannot identify the recovery action, the single-action path is not prominent enough.
elements.implementation_hint: Use the three-part pattern consistently: (1) Acknowledge without blame: 'This did not go through.' (2) Protect what matters: 'Your progress is saved.' (3) Single recovery action: 'Try again.' Amber background (--signal-warn-bg), not red. Shield or info icon, not exclamation mark.

elements.title: Stay Cycle Three-Beat Ritual Interaction Efficiency Test
elements.problem: If the three-beat ritual interaction (arrival signal, cleaning photos, micro-review) requires too much host effort or does not follow a predictable pattern, the rituals become a source of anxiety rather than a remedy. The host must learn the cadence within 2-3 cycles and rely on it for the duration of the lease.
elements.solution: Measure host interaction time and effort for each ritual beat, and track whether engagement becomes more efficient across successive stay cycles.

evidence.quote: The benefits of order are incontestable: it enables us to use space and time to the best advantage, while saving expenditure of mental energy.
evidence.insight: Freud predicts that internalized rituals save mental energy. The test measures whether the three-beat interaction achieves this energy reduction across cycles.

evidence.quote: Urgency should surface first on the dashboard.
evidence.insight: Stay cycle cards must appear in the status zone without requiring the host to navigate. The test verifies that the ritual beats are surfaced proactively.

elements.test_description: Track per-stay-cycle: (1) Host time spent on cleaning photo review (from card render to next action). Target: under 10 seconds for a glance, under 30 seconds for inspection. (2) Micro-review completion time. Target: under 10 seconds. (3) Compare interaction times between cycle 1 (first stay), cycle 3 (third stay), and cycle 8+ (experienced). Measure whether the host's engagement time decreases as they internalize the pattern.
elements.success_criteria: Cleaning photo review time under 10 seconds for 80% of glance interactions. Micro-review completion time under 10 seconds. Interaction time decreases by at least 30% between cycle 1 and cycle 3, indicating pattern internalization.
elements.failure_meaning: If interaction time does not decrease across cycles, the ritual is not becoming predictable -- either the layout changes between visits (violating the fixed-grid principle) or the interaction requires more effort than a glance. If micro-review takes more than 10 seconds, the review interface is too complex.
elements.implementation_hint: The cleaning photo grid should be a fixed 2x2 thumbnail layout viewable without scrolling. Micro-review should use one-tap icon ratings (5 aspects), not text entry. Stay cards must appear in exactly the same dashboard position every visit.

elements.title: Wizard Auto-Save Reliability and Resume Accuracy Test
elements.problem: If auto-save fails silently or the resume experience drops the host at a different step than where they left off, the host's civilizational investment is betrayed. They lose work they already invested, which Freud predicts produces serious disorders -- in platform terms, permanent abandonment.
elements.solution: Automated testing of auto-save reliability, resume accuracy, and local storage fallback across browsers and connectivity conditions.

evidence.quote: If the deprivation is not made good economically, one may be certain of producing serious disorders.
evidence.insight: Lost wizard progress is a deprivation without remedy. The test measures whether the auto-save system prevents this deprivation under all conditions.

evidence.quote: Hosts need to know what's unfinished before a listing goes live. A visible progress indicator on the listing card creates just enough friction to get them to finish.
evidence.insight: The progress indicator is meaningless if progress can be lost. The test verifies that the underlying save mechanism is reliable enough to support the indicator's promise.

elements.test_description: Automated test suite covering: (1) Save latency: measure time from user input to confirmed server save across 100 simulated wizard sessions. Target: under 2000ms in 99% of cases. (2) Resume accuracy: complete steps 1-3, close browser, reopen -- verify the wizard resumes at step 4 with all step 1-3 data intact. (3) Connectivity loss: simulate offline after completing step 2, add input to step 3 while offline, restore connectivity -- verify local storage fallback saves the offline input and reconciles with server on reconnect. (4) Multi-device: save from device A, open from device B -- verify latest state is shown. (5) Browser crash: simulate crash mid-step, reopen -- verify recovery from local storage.
elements.success_criteria: Save latency under 2000ms in 99% of cases. 100% resume accuracy (correct step, all prior data intact) across all test scenarios. Local storage fallback recovers 100% of offline input. Multi-device sync shows correct latest state within 5 seconds.
elements.failure_meaning: Any data loss in the test suite indicates a critical defect in the save-and-resume system. The host's civilizational investment cannot be guaranteed, which undermines the fundamental promise of the pause/reversibility design principle.
elements.implementation_hint: Use a debounced auto-save (2000ms after last input) with local storage as a synchronous write-through. On page load, compare local storage timestamp with server timestamp and use the more recent. Display 'Saved' indicator after every successful server save.

elements.title: Bidirectional Constraint Acknowledgment Interaction Speed Test
elements.problem: If the bidirectional acknowledgment surface takes too long to read or requires too many actions, the host experiences the constraint as bureaucratic friction rather than bidirectional protection. The surface must be readable and actionable within 8 seconds.
elements.solution: Measure time-on-surface for the bidirectional acknowledgment pattern and verify that the three-element content (protection headline, bidirectional explanation, single action) can be absorbed within the target time.

evidence.quote: The first requisite of culture, therefore, is justice.
evidence.insight: Justice must be perceived quickly -- if the bidirectional framing takes too long to read, the host's initial impression of constraint dominates before the protection framing can land.

evidence.quote: The park analogy holds -- you check availability before committing.
evidence.insight: The acknowledgment surface is a low-stakes pause (park bench) before a high-stakes action. It must not feel like a roadblock.

elements.test_description: Show 8 hosts 3 different bidirectional acknowledgment surfaces (date change, proposal decline, schedule modification). Measure: (1) Time from surface appearance to host action (confirm or cancel). Target: under 8 seconds. (2) Can the host restate the bidirectional nature of the constraint after acting? (3) Eye-tracking: does the host read the protection headline before the bidirectional statements?
elements.success_criteria: Average time-on-surface under 8 seconds. At least 6 of 8 hosts can restate the bidirectional constraint after acting. Eye-tracking confirms protection headline is scanned first in at least 6 of 8 participants.
elements.failure_meaning: If time-on-surface exceeds 8 seconds, the surface contains too much text or the content hierarchy is unclear. If hosts cannot restate the bidirectional constraint, the explanation is too subtle or the headline overshadows the body. If the protection headline is not scanned first, the visual hierarchy needs adjustment.
elements.implementation_hint: Keep the protection headline to one short sentence. Keep each bidirectional statement to one sentence. Single primary action button. Total word count on the surface should be under 40 words.

elements.title: Retention One-Action Continuation Conversion Test
elements.problem: If re-listing requires more than one action (navigate to settings, click create new listing, re-enter information), the interaction cost of re-entering civilization exceeds the psychological appeal of stopping. The host defaults to not hosting because stopping is easier than restarting.
elements.solution: Measure the number of actions required to re-list after lease end, and verify that one-tap continuation produces higher re-listing rates than multi-step re-listing.

evidence.quote: We should be much happier if we were to give it up and go back to primitive conditions.
evidence.insight: The host's default desire is to stop hosting (return to primitive conditions). The one-action continuation must make continuing easier than deciding to stop.

evidence.quote: Pause preserves the work, keeps the door open, and costs nothing.
evidence.insight: One-action continuation extends the pause principle to the lease-end moment. The listing is preserved; reactivation costs nothing.

elements.test_description: Track the re-listing funnel: (1) Lease-end card shown to host (event). (2) 'Continue Hosting' tapped (event). (3) Listing reactivated (event). Measure conversion rate at each step and compare with the pre-feature baseline (how many hosts re-listed when required to create a new listing). Track time from lease-end card appearance to reactivation.
elements.success_criteria: Lease-end-to-reactivation conversion rate above 50% within 60 days. Time from 'Continue Hosting' tap to listing reactivation is 0ms perceived (optimistic). Number of actions required: exactly 1 (the tap).
elements.failure_meaning: If conversion is below 50% despite one-action continuation, the retention problem is not primarily about interaction friction -- it is about the host's fundamental decision not to continue (grievances, life changes, market conditions). Investigate qualitative reasons. If the action requires more than 1 tap, the implementation has introduced unintended friction.
elements.implementation_hint: The 'Continue Hosting' button reactivates the existing listing with all prior data preserved. No wizard, no form, no confirmation dialog. The listing returns to active state in one tap. Use optimistic UI (behaves-001 pattern) for instant perceived response.

elements.title: Pre-Civilizational Curiosity Preservation Test
elements.problem: If the discovery experience triggers suspicion rather than curiosity -- through registration walls, premature asks, or platform jargon -- the host's instinctual alarm activates before the platform can demonstrate value. The emotional state shifts from 'interesting' to 'what do they want from me?'
elements.solution: Test whether the discovery landing experience sustains curiosity without triggering defensive suspicion. Measure emotional response before and after the first interaction.

evidence.quote: Any flow that requires users to give information before seeing results will lose most of them.
evidence.insight: Rod's principle establishes the test criterion: discovery must give value without taking information. The test measures whether this is achieved emotionally.

evidence.quote: Our so-called civilization itself is to blame for a great part of our misery.
evidence.insight: Freud predicts that hosts in discovery are unconsciously assessing whether this marketplace is worth the sacrifice. Any premature demand confirms the suspicion that it is not.

elements.test_description: Recruit 8 prospective hosts who have never used Split Lease. Show each the discovery landing page. Ask them to think aloud as they explore. Measure: (1) First verbal reaction (categorize as curiosity, suspicion, neutral, or confusion). (2) Time before the first defensive statement ('What do they want?' or 'Do I have to sign up?'). (3) Whether they encounter any registration wall, form field, or identity request before seeing earnings data or demand signals.
elements.success_criteria: At least 6 of 8 hosts express curiosity as their first verbal reaction. No host encounters a registration wall or form field before seeing at least one value signal (earnings estimate, demand data). Average time before any defensive statement exceeds 60 seconds.
elements.failure_meaning: If curiosity is not the dominant first reaction, the discovery page is either visually unwelcoming (cold containment, corporate feel) or content-leading with demands rather than value. If any registration wall appears before value, the progressive disclosure sequence is violated at the first phase.
elements.implementation_hint: Discovery must be entirely anonymous: no sign-up, no cookies accepted, no form fields. Show geo-localized earnings estimates, demand signals, and host success stories before any call-to-action. The first CTA should be 'See what your space could earn' -- exploratory, not committal.

elements.title: Agent Continuity Through Onboarding Emotional Transfer Test
elements.problem: If the transition from the agent call to the digital platform feels like a handoff to a system (generic welcome messages, no agent reference, impersonal verification flow), the host experiences Freud's 'element of disappointment' -- the warm human connection is replaced by cold mechanics. Trust built with the agent does not transfer to the platform.
elements.solution: Test whether the agent's name, photo, and call-specific references in the onboarding flow sustain the emotional warmth of the call.

evidence.quote: Authentication should be invisible until it matters.
evidence.insight: The onboarding flow must feel like a continuation of the call, not a transition to a bureaucratic process. The test measures whether the agent's presence achieves this.

evidence.quote: The members of the community have restricted their possibilities of gratification, whereas the individual recognized no such restrictions.
evidence.insight: Onboarding is the first restriction. The agent relationship mediates this restriction. The test measures whether the mediation is effective.

elements.test_description: Recruit 6 hosts who have recently completed an agent call. Show each the onboarding flow. Ask after each screen: (1) 'Does this feel like it is connected to your call with [agent name]?' (2) 'Does this feel personal or generic?' Track whether the agent's name appears on each screen, whether call-specific details are referenced, and whether any screen feels disconnected from the call experience.
elements.success_criteria: At least 5 of 6 hosts rate the onboarding flow as 'connected' to the call experience. No screen is rated as 'generic' by more than 2 hosts. The agent's name or photo appears on every onboarding screen.
elements.failure_meaning: If the onboarding feels disconnected from the call, the agent presence is either absent or too subtle. If any screen feels generic, it needs personalization: agent name, call-specific property references, or language that echoes the call vocabulary.
elements.implementation_hint: Display the agent's avatar and name in the onboarding header. Pre-fill property type, location, and unit count from the call notes. Use copy that references the call: 'Bryant mentioned your two units in [neighborhood]. Let us get them set up.'

elements.title: Dignified Surrender Emotional Arc Through Listing Wizard Test
elements.problem: If the listing wizard treats each step as a routine form submission rather than as a dignified exchange, hosts experience the peak of instinctual renunciation as bureaucratic drudgery. The emotional target is pride -- the feeling that creating a listing is an achievement -- but the default experience is depletion.
elements.solution: Test whether hosts feel pride, depletion, or indifference at each wizard step. Verify that benefit statements and completion acknowledgments shift the emotional register toward pride.

evidence.quote: It is impossible to ignore the extent to which civilization is built up on renunciation of instinctual gratifications.
evidence.insight: Each wizard step is a renunciation. The test measures whether the platform's emotional design converts this renunciation from felt cost into felt achievement.

evidence.quote: Completion percentage is a good host nudge. Hosts need to know what's unfinished before a listing goes live.
evidence.insight: The completion indicator should feel like encouragement, not a reminder of what is owed. The test measures the emotional charge of the indicator.

elements.test_description: Recruit 6 hosts to complete the listing wizard in a moderated session. At each step transition, pause and ask: (1) 'How do you feel right now?' (categorize as proud/encouraged, neutral, depleted/frustrated). (2) 'Do you feel like the platform values what you just provided?' After completion, ask: (3) 'How do you feel about your listing now that it is complete?' Rate on a 5-point pride scale.
elements.success_criteria: At least 4 of 6 hosts express pride or encouragement at the photo upload step (the most intimate disclosure). Post-completion pride rating averages above 3.5 out of 5. No host rates any step as 'frustrated' after seeing the benefit statement that precedes it.
elements.failure_meaning: If pride is not the dominant emotion at completion, the benefit statements are not compelling enough or the completion celebration is too muted. If frustration appears at any step, the renunciation at that step is not offset by sufficient value delivery.
elements.implementation_hint: Before each step's input fields, display a one-sentence benefit statement in the reassurance register. After each step completion, show an acknowledgment: 'Nice -- your space details are set. Two more steps to go.' At completion, use a full-card celebration state with the listing preview.

elements.title: Proposal Review Confidence Transformation Test
elements.problem: If the proposal experience does not transform the host's initial alarm (stranger seeking entry) into confident assessment (informed decision-making), the host either freezes (no response) or declines defensively. The emotional arc must move from alarm to assessment to decision within the proposal interaction.
elements.solution: Measure the host's emotional state at proposal open, after scanning trust signals, and after making a decision. Verify the arc moves from anxiety to confidence.

evidence.quote: Men are not gentle, friendly creatures wishing for love.
evidence.insight: The host's initial response to a stranger is instinctual distrust. The test measures whether the proposal experience transforms this distrust into informed judgment.

evidence.quote: A well-structured proposal activates the host to respond.
evidence.insight: Activation requires confidence. The test measures whether the proposal's structure produces the confidence needed for the host to act rather than freeze.

elements.test_description: Recruit 8 hosts with active listings. Show each a realistic proposal notification. Measure emotional state at three points: (1) On notification ('You have a new proposal') -- rate on anxiety scale. (2) After scanning the trust block (verification, leases, rating, purpose) -- rate on confidence scale. (3) After making a decision (accept, counter, decline) -- rate on satisfaction scale. Track whether the emotional arc consistently moves from higher anxiety to higher confidence.
elements.success_criteria: Anxiety score decreases by at least 2 points (on a 7-point scale) between notification and trust-block scan. Confidence score increases by at least 2 points between notification and decision. At least 6 of 8 hosts report feeling 'confident' or 'informed' at the decision point.
elements.failure_meaning: If anxiety does not decrease after the trust block scan, the trust signals are either insufficient, not prominent enough, or not trusted by the host. If confidence does not increase, the proposal lacks the information the host needs to make a comfortable decision. Investigate which information is missing.
elements.implementation_hint: The notification should be warm, not alarming: 'You have a new proposal to review.' The trust block should be the first thing visible when the proposal opens. Track the emotional arc across multiple proposals for the same host to see if confidence improves with experience.

elements.title: Active-Lease Calm Sustenance Through Ritual Predictability Test
elements.problem: If the active lease experience does not sustain calm through predictable ritual, the host's anxiety oscillates between comfort and vigilance with each stay cycle. Without ritual predictability, information voids between stays fill with imagined threats rather than confirmed order.
elements.solution: Survey hosts at multiple points during an active lease to measure their baseline anxiety and track whether ritual completion correlates with emotional calm.

evidence.quote: Order is a kind of repetition-compulsion by which it is ordained once for all when, where and how a thing shall be done so that on every similar occasion doubt and hesitation shall be avoided.
evidence.insight: Freud predicts that ritual predictability produces calm through repetition. The test measures whether this prediction holds across a lease's duration.

evidence.quote: Urgency should surface first on the dashboard.
evidence.insight: The dashboard must surface ritual confirmations as status updates, not urgent actions. The emotional register should be comfort, not urgency.

elements.test_description: Embed a single-question pulse survey in the host dashboard at stay cycle 1, 4, 8, and 12: 'How comfortable are you with your current arrangement?' (1-5 scale). Correlate comfort scores with: (1) ritual completion rate for the preceding stays, (2) number of information voids (missed cleaning photos, late arrival confirmations). Track whether comfort increases across cycles for hosts with high ritual completion and decreases for hosts with low ritual completion.
elements.success_criteria: Comfort score increases by at least 0.5 points between stay 1 and stay 8 for hosts with ritual completion above 70%. Negative correlation between information voids and comfort score (r < -0.3). No host with 100% ritual completion rates their comfort below 3 out of 5.
elements.failure_meaning: If comfort does not increase across cycles, the rituals may be perceived as chores rather than reassurance. If no correlation exists between information voids and discomfort, the host may not rely on the rituals for anxiety management -- investigate whether they are using alternative channels (direct communication with guest) instead.
elements.implementation_hint: The pulse survey should appear as an unobtrusive inline question within the dashboard, not a modal popup. One tap to answer, no follow-up. Collect responses passively without disrupting the host's dashboard experience.

elements.title: Platform Constraint Safety Perception Test
elements.problem: If the host's cumulative emotional experience of platform constraints is 'I am being controlled' rather than 'I am being protected,' civilizational antagonism accumulates. This antagonism is invisible until retention, where it crystallizes as a reason not to re-list.
